As announced a month ago, TIIE NEWS-LETTER Board has decided to award a prize for
the best design for a new cover for the paper. The time limit is now up, but we have decided to extend it until Monday, January 4th, as only a few designs have been handed in. The
conditions of the contest will be found in the second number previous to this.

The Board of THE NEWS-LETTER takes great pleasure in announcing the election to the
staff of Mr. Nathan Williams Haynes, 1912. Mr. Haynes will take the position of Assistant Athletic Editor. Mr. Haynes is the first member of the Freshman Class to be elected to an office on
THE NEWS-LETTER, but we expect to elect one more Freshman this year.

derstanding of modern institutions and modern

preparation for the study of our modern systems, and some knowledge of Greek and Roman literature is necessary for the full appreciation cf much of our highest English poetry.
For the art and culture of ancient Greece are
still among the richest parts of our inheritance.
And, as Mr. Lowell once said on a notable occasion, "The garners of Sicily are empty now,
but the bees from all climes still fetch honey
from the tiny garden plot of Theocritus. On
a map of the world you may cover Judea with
your thumb, Athens with a finger tip, and
neither of them figures in the Prices-Current;
but they still lord it in the thought and action
of every civilized man."

THE PITIFUL COMPLAINT OF THE
POOR HOPKINS STUDENT.
1.
Last Saturday night at eleven o'clock
I looked in my purse—and, oh! what a shock!
Not a nickel I found to pay my car-fare
(At seven o'clock five dollars was there).
I searched, but in vain, and one word I spoke—
"Broke"

Chances in raffles I'd bought, six or seven;
The girls crowded round me, I thought it was
heaven;
But rallies cost money, I learnt to my cost;
Departed five dollars—gone—thrown away—
lost!
But one word I have, and oft be it spoke—
"Broke !"

No Christmas for me, and no gifts to my
friends;
Thank goodness, it's over now—everything
ends—
The Cosmovilla is only a thing of the past,
But my busted condition a long time will last.
For many a month I'll continue to croak:
"Broke !"
S. C. C., who has suffered.

LIFE IN MUNICH.
Mr. H. J. Hughes, 'oS, who, since graduation, has been studying at Munich, wrote the
following letter to his parents, little thinking
that it would ever be published in the NEWSLETTER. A member of the University, however, was present when it was received, and
requested that he be allowed to publish it in
THE NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR FOLKS:
The University is now in full swing. I have
just come from paying my 68M. tuition fee,
and I suppose that is the first step toward
making me a full-fledged student. The work
is still hard. I mean, to understand the teachers. Many parts of the lectures are now lost
on me, yet I hope that, as I become acquainted
with the professors' style of talking and my
vocabulary grows, this difficulty will be overcome. I decided to give up one of the courses
I wanted to take. At least, to postpone it until
next semester. You see, everything here goes
by semesters. The University closes about
March 15 for a month. All the courses end
then. When they are resumed again in April,
it is as if the University were starting anew.
The German student never stays at one university for his four years' work. He goes to
at least four different ones. Here a semester,
there a semester, usually remaining four terms
at that university from which he wishes his degree. There are no examinations—you simply
study for four years, and at the end of that
Period take a final examination, which, if
passed, makes you a doctor of medicine, or
whatever other branch you may have passed.
As it is, I have 17 hours of lectures, three each
day and two on Saturday. The course I
dropped was an excellent one, given by one of
the foremost men in Germany, Dr. Brentano.
The courses I am taking will, I believe, prepare me in German for the real work next
year. As I have to do my reading with a dictionary, it goes slowly, especially as the subjects contain many words one never meets in
ordinary reading.
The praiseworthy characteristic of the University, and of all German universities, in fact,
is that the student is not placed under an instructor with little experience in teaching. The
men here are, as a general rule, old men. Each

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

man has made a name for himself by his research work, his works published and his record at the university from which he was called
to fill the chair at Munich. The man who
gives the general world history is private advisor to the Prince Regent of Bavaria. One
of George's (George Abel, 'o8) professors is
the most celebrated man in the world in physics, Dr. Roentgen. And so it goes, each man
a "star," an authority in himself, whose books
are well known in university circles. That
seems to be the road to fame--the publication
of books.
As forlorn and dreary looking as is the old
part of the University, just so wonderfully
beautiful is the new. I really seem to be wandering in a palace in fairy land, when I recollect it is only a university, and not a kingly
palace. The halls are immense and wide, with
mosaic floors. The staircases and doorways
are of beautiful Circassian marble. Over all
are exquisite mosaics, beautiful fountains and
electric light brackets of beaten iron. At the
bottom of the main staircase is an immense
open space, softly lighted from the dome
above. The main hall seats 1,200 people. It
is in brown and white, with a wonderful skylight of stained glass and heavy mahogany
door with a gold pattern. In the class rooms
are hardwood floors, soft cream-colored curtains with green borders, and one sees everywhere in the corridors and rooms excellent
taste in the selection of the furnishings. The
doors are of frosted glass with wood pattern.
They have any number of rooms seating 200,
the seats being arranged as in a theatre. Never
did I imagine a university could be so lavishly
built.
(To be continued.)

SAMMY'S "SCOOP."
craziest looking little chap in
the
was
He
the world; pug-nosed, red-headed, freckledface, and about as big as a minute, when he
got his job as night-boy on the Daily Blab.
He was, however, always cheerful and willing, and his funny little face wore "a smile
that won't come off." His queer looks, droll
sayings and everlasting good nature made him
a prime favorite and we all forgot how "unbeautiful" he was. Before he had been in

the office a week he wormed his way into
everyone's heart from old "Pop Fitch," the
Managing Editor, down to the telegraph
operators. He was an encyclopedia of crime
and sport and the boys soon learned to use
him as a reference book on these subjects. He
could tell you as much about any murderer or
confidence game, baseball player or racehorse as you would find in an hour's hunt
anywhere else. He had a vocabulary of
original and selected slang that would turn
Billy Baxter in his grave and drive "The
Chorus Lady" to drink, could they have
heard him. Each day the Giants were "at
home" he would be there, for working at
night gave him the afternoons free unless he
slept, but sleep with ball game on. His
quaint descriptions of plays that won and lost
games up at the Polo Grounds, his scalding
criticisms of the players, his slangy similies
crept into the Blab so often that the paper be-

came famous for its -basball news and Alf
Macy, who was doing that stuff those days,
won a reputation as a wit.
For three years Sammy worked in the
editorial rooms, carrying copy, going out for
the men's midnight lunches, and doing other
odd jobs. Then there happened one of those
unexpected things, which are always bobbing
up in a newspaper office and which make
journalism the most fascinating game in the
world. The Typographical Union gave a
picnic and that evening only about half our
pressmen and stereotypers reported; the rest
were recovering from the entertainment. The
foreman of the press-room found his force so
short that unless he could get a couple of men
somewhere he would not be able to run the
presses. He went up to the composing-room,
but there they needed all their men on the
linotype machines. Then he came to the
editorial-rooms.
"There's Sammy. Will he do?" was the
answer he received.
"He'll do," said the foreman and so Sammy
went down stairs for the first time,
The three years Sammy had worked for The
Blab had made a great change in the boy. In
spite of the hard night hours he had grown
like a weed, and if he was not handsome—
well you could look at him without laughing:
a metamorphosis that was little short of a

things happened. The Blab was running an

Sammy had been with the stereotypers

"Naw," answered the other, "he's strong
for the paper, and I'm sure you can't get
him to come out with us. If we sound him,
he's just wise enough to tumble to the game

That evening the night door clerk was
thunderstruck to see Sammy walking at the
head of the old stereotyping force. They got
out the paper, and it was not short a single
copy. Sammy had his pay doubled, and he
deserved it, as the press-room foreman said,
"We couldn't have even gotten out one of
those rocky, no-mail edition papers."
All this was three years ago, and Sammy
is now foreman of the stereotyping department, and if some day word is passed round
the office that there is a new manager of the
mechanical departments, most of us will be
willing to bet pretty high stakes that his
name is Sammy, or rather, Mr. Samuel
Morgan.

And thus the humblest of the learned throng
Gains deepest knowledge of this earth of
ours:
The pilgrims on the path most lone and long
Shall reach the coolest shade and sweetest
flowers;
And he who out of weakness is made strong
Hath leagued himself with the eternal
powers.—REGINALD A. BECKETT.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE HARESFOOT CLUB.

LACROSSE.
Editor News Letter—
No article has as yet appeared in THE
NEWS-LETTER concerning lacrosse. It is most
natural that this spring sport should be kept in
the background during the football season, but
now that our gridiron warriors have completed
their glorious and most successful season, the
time has come when we should look forward
to achieving fresh laurels for Hopkins.
There are a number of men in this University who desire to become athletes, but who
modestly imagine they lack the talent. It is to
such men that lacrosse offers a salvation. Diligent practice, coupled with a little coaching,
makes the expert. There is no excess training
required nor any particular response; only
steady work and a willing spirit.
It seems to be the general opinion of the
fellows that there are but very few positions
on the team open this year. Such a report is
unfounded and wholly false. The veterans at
the Medical School are very uncertain in attendance, and at best cannot in any sense be
relied upon to fill their positions next spring.
Just recently one was taken seriously ill with
typhoid, while another is to leave for Europe in
April, thus incapacitating two of our best men.
The loss of these, together with the absence of
Meyers, Blanck, Armstrong, k. Williams and
Mathias, who have left the University, will
make it necessary to develop material for the
coming season.
The squad has already been called out, and
is hard at work to establish a new record by
winning the fourth consecutive inter-collegiate
championship of the United States.
Besides, there is coming the series of class
games. So beware, Sophomores and Freshmen! Look to your laurels. Buy a stick—get
busy—talk and play lacrosse.

CAPTAIN H. S. FRANK.

On Monday night, December 7, a meeting
of the Dramatic Club was held. A constitution was adopted and the following officers
were elected:
President—Mr. Hamilton Owens, 19o9.
Vice-President—Mr. Alan C. Woods, 1910.
Treasurer—Mr. W. Howard Michael, 1909.
Secretary—A Ir. Benjamin Weems, 1909.
Stage Manager—Mr. Williams Haynes,

1912.
These, with Messrs. Stollenwerck and Pedrick, make up the executative committee. It
was decided to call the club "The Haresfoot
Club."
Plans were discussed and it was decided to
present some farce, to be chosen by the executative committee, next February. A more definite announcement, plans, dates and trips will
be made later. Membership is subject to election by the executative committee, of which
Mr. Woods is chairman and Mr. Weems secretary.

THE FOOTBALL BLOWOUT.
The football blowout, held in the Cage on
Saturday night, December 12, proved to be enjoyable in a slap-stick sort of way to the undergraduates, who were present almost to a
man.
Besides speeches by Dr. Renouf, who presented the "H's," and Captain Stockton and
Manager Bally, and the usual tug of war, there
was a boxing match between Lawton and
Beehler, both '12. Neither men knew much
about the game, but they made up in speed
what they lacked in science, and for the two
rounds they went they mixed things up some.
The musical end was attended to by three
-gentlemen of culloh," who, backed up by a
banjo and a guitar, succeeded in stirring up the
echoes in the cage by means of their powerful
lungs. "Mistah Thomas," one of the three,
was undoubtedly some pumpkins in the buck
dancing line.
The .feed that followed was up to the standard set by the rest of the show, and one of the
Freshmen was heard to say after the lights
had been put out that he had eaten "four
blocks:'

HOPKINS INDOOR MEET.

A

The track team management has again secured the use of the Fifth Regiment Armory
for an indoor athletic meet. This event, which
brings to Baltimore the best college track and
field men of any meet held here, will be held
Saturday evening, January 3oth. Some exceptional relay races will be run, for, according
to our usual custom, we will have a mile race
with the University of Virginia, and invitations have been sent to Princeton and Columbia
to run teams in the four-mile event, where
Hopkins will also be represented.
Managers Stewart, Wolfe and Glanzer are
working hard for the success of this meet,
which will be run, as all Hopkins track meets,
in a business-like way, with no long "stage
waits" to tire the spectators and with ideal conditions for the contestants. As usual, a Games
Committee will be appointed to assist in this
work.
The program includes open-to-all events in
the too and 220-yard dashes, 44o, 88o, and mile
runs, the high and broad jumps, and the pole
vault. There will also be a 100-yard dash and
440-yard run, open to schoolboys, and a 220
for midgets. Relay races will be held to suit
the entries that will be made.
Invitations to enter in these games have
been sent out to more than a hundred and fifty
colleges, schools and athletic clubs, and a long

list of star entries is assured. The games have
always proved to be one of Hopkins' star athletic attractions, and those to be held this
season to promise to even outshine its brilliant
predecessors.
Hopkins is to be represented in the to-mile
run that is to be held in Washington on New
Year's Day, Griffith, Bryer, Reeside, Russell,
Wolfe and Stocket having entered. These are
the men who won the Cross-Country Club's
banner this fall, and their prospects are excellent for capturing the event in the Capital.

FRESHMAN-SOPHOMORE GAME.
A single goal from placement, kicked by
McCabe, the Sophomore halfback, won the inter-class football game for the second-year
men. Contrary to the expectations of everyone, the Freshmen played a fast, plucky game;
in fact, most thought that they outplayed the
upper classmen. Fulton and Beehler, the
Freshman halfbacks, repeatedly tore up the
heavier line of their opponents, and, had there
been a few more minutes to play, would have
scored a touchdown, for when the whistle blew
for the end of the game the Freshmen held the
ball for first down within the Sophomores' toyard line. The cane rush proved easy meat
for the Freshies. They picked fast, wiry men
to represent them, and these, getting the jump
on the Sophs at the start, fairly covered the

COTILLON CLUB DANCE.
The first of the Cotillon Club dances was
held on Friday night, December 4, 1908, in McCoy Hall. The dance started promptly at 9,
and the last dance was whirled away as the 12
o'clock bell rang.
In spite of the rain, which had lasted all the
afternoon up until 8 in the evening, the dance
was very well attended. There were about
75 couples present, and 25 or 30 stags. It was
a great source of satisfaction to the Board of
Governors to see so many of the chaperons
present. Among these were Dr. and Mrs.
Lorraine Hulburt, Dr. and Mrs. Henry Wood,
Dr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Dr. and
Mrs. Murray P. Brush, Mrs. Hall Harris, Jr.,
and Mrs. Paul Haupt. Those there are to be
congratulated, and we hope to see more at the
next dance, which very likely will be held
sometime in February.
The floor was cleaner than usual, and well
waxed, so that green Freshmen could slip, slide
and bump into sedate upper classmen and professors to their heart's content. The music
was divine; "ravishing," as one learned Senior
expressed it, and, although the orchestra might
have given more encores in the after-supper
dances, and made them a little longer, the general sentiment is that Emerich and his choice
orchestra could have done no better. The only
fault to be found with any of the arrangements
is that the caterer might have made better
arrangements. True that the salad was hot,
but the ice-cream was cold—when it was not
on hot plates. Perhaps it would not be unwise
for the Board to change caterers and see if another would not be more satisfactory.
However, the general opinion of those who
came to see what the dances are like is that
they are most assuredly coming to both the
others.

HOPKINS NIGHT.
Hopkins night, which was held at Ford's
Opera House on December IIth, proved to be
a howling success. The theater was tastefully
decorated with Hopkins colors and class banners, and there was a large and appreciative
audience present. The play itself, "The Girl
Question," was certainly suited to the occasion,
as it represented a topic that everyone present
was deeply interested in, especially those who
did not go to "stay."
Far more interesting, however, was the spirit
shown, not only by the students, but by the

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
The memorial meeting in honor of Professor
Brooks was held in the Donovan room on Sunday, December 6th. A large audience was
present, and addresses were made by several
members of the faculty. A very interesting
account of Dr. Brooks' life and work, by Associate Professor Ethan A. Andrews, will be
found in the last number of Science.
At a recent meeting of the Freshman Class
Gerhard Schmeisser was elected captain of the
Freshman lacrosse team. Captain Schmeisser
is a brother of "Bill" and Harry, both former
stars on the "'varsity." There is a great deal
of good material in the Freshman Class, and
he hopes to develop a team that will give the
Sophomores a hard rub.

THE PITIFUL COMPLAINT OF THE
POOR HOPKINS STUDENT.
1.
Last Saturday night at eleven o'clock
I looked in my purse—and, oh! what a shock!
Not a nickel I found to pay my car-fare
(At seven o'clock five dollars was there).
I searched, but in vain, and one word I spoke—
"Broke"

Chances in raffles I'd bought, six or seven;
The girls crowded round me, I thought it was
heaven;
But rallies cost money, I learnt to my cost;
Departed five dollars—gone—thrown away—
lost!
But one word I have, and oft be it spoke—
"Broke !"

No Christmas for me, and no gifts to my
friends;
Thank goodness, it's over now—everything
ends—
The Cosmovilla is only a thing of the past,
But my busted condition a long time will last.
For many a month I'll continue to croak:
"Broke !"
S. C. C., who has suffered.

LIFE IN MUNICH.
Mr. H. J. Hughes, 'oS, who, since graduation, has been studying at Munich, wrote the
following letter to his parents, little thinking
that it would ever be published in the NEWSLETTER. A member of the University, however, was present when it was received, and
requested that he be allowed to publish it in
THE NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR FOLKS:
The University is now in full swing. I have
just come from paying my 68M. tuition fee,
and I suppose that is the first step toward
making me a full-fledged student. The work
is still hard. I mean, to understand the teachers. Many parts of the lectures are now lost
on me, yet I hope that, as I become acquainted
with the professors' style of talking and my
vocabulary grows, this difficulty will be overcome. I decided to give up one of the courses
I wanted to take. At least, to postpone it until
next semester. You see, everything here goes
by semesters. The University closes about
March 15 for a month. All the courses end
then. When they are resumed again in April,
it is as if the University were starting anew.
The German student never stays at one university for his four years' work. He goes to
at least four different ones. Here a semester,
there a semester, usually remaining four terms
at that university from which he wishes his degree. There are no examinations—you simply
study for four years, and at the end of that
Period take a final examination, which, if
passed, makes you a doctor of medicine, or
whatever other branch you may have passed.
As it is, I have 17 hours of lectures, three each
day and two on Saturday. The course I
dropped was an excellent one, given by one of
the foremost men in Germany, Dr. Brentano.
The courses I am taking will, I believe, prepare me in German for the real work next
year. As I have to do my reading with a dictionary, it goes slowly, especially as the subjects contain many words one never meets in
ordinary reading.
The praiseworthy characteristic of the University, and of all German universities, in fact,
is that the student is not placed under an instructor with little experience in teaching. The
men here are, as a general rule, old men. Each

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

man has made a name for himself by his research work, his works published and his record at the university from which he was called
to fill the chair at Munich. The man who
gives the general world history is private advisor to the Prince Regent of Bavaria. One
of George's (George Abel, 'o8) professors is
the most celebrated man in the world in physics, Dr. Roentgen. And so it goes, each man
a "star," an authority in himself, whose books
are well known in university circles. That
seems to be the road to fame--the publication
of books.
As forlorn and dreary looking as is the old
part of the University, just so wonderfully
beautiful is the new. I really seem to be wandering in a palace in fairy land, when I recollect it is only a university, and not a kingly
palace. The halls are immense and wide, with
mosaic floors. The staircases and doorways
are of beautiful Circassian marble. Over all
are exquisite mosaics, beautiful fountains and
electric light brackets of beaten iron. At the
bottom of the main staircase is an immense
open space, softly lighted from the dome
above. The main hall seats 1,200 people. It
is in brown and white, with a wonderful skylight of stained glass and heavy mahogany
door with a gold pattern. In the class rooms
are hardwood floors, soft cream-colored curtains with green borders, and one sees everywhere in the corridors and rooms excellent
taste in the selection of the furnishings. The
doors are of frosted glass with wood pattern.
They have any number of rooms seating 200,
the seats being arranged as in a theatre. Never
did I imagine a university could be so lavishly
built.
(To be continued.)

spite of the hard night hours he had grown
like a weed, and if he was not handsome—

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE HARESFOOT CLUB.

LACROSSE.
Editor News Letter—
No article has as yet appeared in THE
NEWS-LETTER concerning lacrosse. It is most
natural that this spring sport should be kept in
the background during the football season, but
now that our gridiron warriors have completed
their glorious and most successful season, the
time has come when we should look forward
to achieving fresh laurels for Hopkins.
There are a number of men in this University who desire to become athletes, but who
modestly imagine they lack the talent. It is to
such men that lacrosse offers a salvation. Diligent practice, coupled with a little coaching,
makes the expert. There is no excess training
required nor any particular response; only
steady work and a willing spirit.
It seems to be the general opinion of the
fellows that there are but very few positions
on the team open this year. Such a report is
unfounded and wholly false. The veterans at
the Medical School are very uncertain in attendance, and at best cannot in any sense be
relied upon to fill their positions next spring.
Just recently one was taken seriously ill with
typhoid, while another is to leave for Europe in
April, thus incapacitating two of our best men.
The loss of these, together with the absence of
Meyers, Blanck, Armstrong, k. Williams and
Mathias, who have left the University, will
make it necessary to develop material for the
coming season.
The squad has already been called out, and
is hard at work to establish a new record by
winning the fourth consecutive inter-collegiate
championship of the United States.
Besides, there is coming the series of class
games. So beware, Sophomores and Freshmen! Look to your laurels. Buy a stick—get
busy—talk and play lacrosse.

CAPTAIN H. S. FRANK.

On Monday night, December 7, a meeting
of the Dramatic Club was held. A constitution was adopted and the following officers
were elected:
President—Mr. Hamilton Owens, 19o9.
Vice-President—Mr. Alan C. Woods, 1910.
Treasurer—Mr. W. Howard Michael, 1909.
Secretary—A Ir. Benjamin Weems, 1909.
Stage Manager—Mr. Williams Haynes,

1912.
These, with Messrs. Stollenwerck and Pedrick, make up the executative committee. It
was decided to call the club "The Haresfoot
Club."
Plans were discussed and it was decided to
present some farce, to be chosen by the executative committee, next February. A more definite announcement, plans, dates and trips will
be made later. Membership is subject to election by the executative committee, of which
Mr. Woods is chairman and Mr. Weems secretary.

THE FOOTBALL BLOWOUT.
The football blowout, held in the Cage on
Saturday night, December 12, proved to be enjoyable in a slap-stick sort of way to the undergraduates, who were present almost to a
man.
Besides speeches by Dr. Renouf, who presented the "H's," and Captain Stockton and
Manager Bally, and the usual tug of war, there
was a boxing match between Lawton and
Beehler, both '12. Neither men knew much
about the game, but they made up in speed
what they lacked in science, and for the two
rounds they went they mixed things up some.
The musical end was attended to by three
-gentlemen of culloh," who, backed up by a
banjo and a guitar, succeeded in stirring up the
echoes in the cage by means of their powerful
lungs. "Mistah Thomas," one of the three,
was undoubtedly some pumpkins in the buck
dancing line.
The .feed that followed was up to the standard set by the rest of the show, and one of the
Freshmen was heard to say after the lights
had been put out that he had eaten "four
blocks:'

HOPKINS INDOOR MEET.

A

The track team management has again secured the use of the Fifth Regiment Armory
for an indoor athletic meet. This event, which
brings to Baltimore the best college track and
field men of any meet held here, will be held
Saturday evening, January 3oth. Some exceptional relay races will be run, for, according
to our usual custom, we will have a mile race
with the University of Virginia, and invitations have been sent to Princeton and Columbia
to run teams in the four-mile event, where
Hopkins will also be represented.
Managers Stewart, Wolfe and Glanzer are
working hard for the success of this meet,
which will be run, as all Hopkins track meets,
in a business-like way, with no long "stage
waits" to tire the spectators and with ideal conditions for the contestants. As usual, a Games
Committee will be appointed to assist in this
work.
The program includes open-to-all events in
the too and 220-yard dashes, 44o, 88o, and mile
runs, the high and broad jumps, and the pole
vault. There will also be a 100-yard dash and
440-yard run, open to schoolboys, and a 220
for midgets. Relay races will be held to suit
the entries that will be made.
Invitations to enter in these games have
been sent out to more than a hundred and fifty
colleges, schools and athletic clubs, and a long

list of star entries is assured. The games have
always proved to be one of Hopkins' star athletic attractions, and those to be held this
season to promise to even outshine its brilliant
predecessors.
Hopkins is to be represented in the to-mile
run that is to be held in Washington on New
Year's Day, Griffith, Bryer, Reeside, Russell,
Wolfe and Stocket having entered. These are
the men who won the Cross-Country Club's
banner this fall, and their prospects are excellent for capturing the event in the Capital.

A single goal from placement, kicked by
McCabe, the Sophomore halfback, won the inter-class football game for the second-year

upper classmen. Fulton and Beehler, the

heavier line of their opponents, and, had there
been a few more minutes to play, would have
scored a touchdown, for when the whistle blew
for the end of the game the Freshmen held the
ball for first down within the Sophomores' toyard line. The cane rush proved easy meat
for the Freshies. They picked fast, wiry men
to represent them, and these, getting the jump
on the Sophs at the start, fairly covered the

COTILLON CLUB DANCE.
The first of the Cotillon Club dances was
held on Friday night, December 4, 1908, in McCoy Hall. The dance started promptly at 9,
and the last dance was whirled away as the 12
o'clock bell rang.
In spite of the rain, which had lasted all the
afternoon up until 8 in the evening, the dance
was very well attended. There were about
75 couples present, and 25 or 30 stags. It was
a great source of satisfaction to the Board of
Governors to see so many of the chaperons
present. Among these were Dr. and Mrs.
Lorraine Hulburt, Dr. and Mrs. Henry Wood,
Dr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Dr. and
Mrs. Murray P. Brush, Mrs. Hall Harris, Jr.,
and Mrs. Paul Haupt. Those there are to be
congratulated, and we hope to see more at the
next dance, which very likely will be held
sometime in February.
The floor was cleaner than usual, and well
waxed, so that green Freshmen could slip, slide
and bump into sedate upper classmen and professors to their heart's content. The music
was divine; "ravishing," as one learned Senior
expressed it, and, although the orchestra might
have given more encores in the after-supper
dances, and made them a little longer, the general sentiment is that Emerich and his choice
orchestra could have done no better. The only
fault to be found with any of the arrangements
is that the caterer might have made better
arrangements. True that the salad was hot,
but the ice-cream was cold—when it was not
on hot plates. Perhaps it would not be unwise
for the Board to change caterers and see if another would not be more satisfactory.
However, the general opinion of those who
came to see what the dances are like is that
they are most assuredly coming to both the
others.

HOPKINS NIGHT.
Hopkins night, which was held at Ford's
Opera House on December IIth, proved to be
a howling success. The theater was tastefully
decorated with Hopkins colors and class banners, and there was a large and appreciative
audience present. The play itself, "The Girl
Question," was certainly suited to the occasion,
as it represented a topic that everyone present
was deeply interested in, especially those who
did not go to "stay."

UNIVERSITY NOTES.
The memorial meeting in honor of Professor
Brooks was held in the Donovan room on Sunday, December 6th. A large audience was
present, and addresses were made by several
members of the faculty. A very interesting
account of Dr. Brooks' life and work, by Associate Professor Ethan A. Andrews, will be
found in the last number of Science.
At a recent meeting of the Freshman Class
Gerhard Schmeisser was elected captain of the
Freshman lacrosse team. Captain Schmeisser
is a brother of "Bill" and Harry, both former
stars on the "'varsity." There is a great deal
of good material in the Freshman Class, and
he hopes to develop a team that will give the
Sophomores a hard rub.

The undergraduate matriculation was held
on December loth. Appropriate addresses
were made by President Remsen, Dean Griffin,
Dr. M. P. Brush and Dr. Buchner. Sixty-one
received their certificates.
Dr. Ernest Flagg Henderson on December
15th gave a lecture on "Regime of Robespierre," the last of his series of lectures on the
French Revolution. These lectures have been
exceedingly interesting and instructive, and
have been greatly appreciated by everyone who
has attended them.
